title: 104_s1989
content: The Act may be cited as the "Fort Peck Reservation Rural Water System Act of 1996". It includes findings and purpose. The Fort Peck Reservation Rural Water System Act of 1996 aims to provide safe and adequate water supplies to residents of the Fort Peck Indian Reservation in Montana, as there is a lack of sufficient water systems meeting health and safety standards. The Act recognizes the trust responsibility of the United States to ensure access to reliable water sources, with the Missouri River identified as the best option. The Fort Peck Reservation Rural Water System Act of 1996 defines key terms such as the Fort Peck tribe, Pick-Sloan program, Secretary, and Water System. The Act aims to provide safe water to residents of the Fort Peck Indian Reservation in Montana. The Fort Peck Reservation Rural Water System, authorized by the Secretary, includes pumping and treatment facilities near Poplar, Montana, pipelines throughout the Fort Peck Indian Reservation, and future interconnections to other areas outside the reservation. The Fort Peck Reservation Rural Water System includes facilities in Montana to serve the needs of the Fort Peck Indian Reservation, including water systems, buildings, access roads, property rights, and electrical power facilities. Additional pipelines, pumping plants, and facilities may be added as needed. The Secretary will provide necessary water supply infrastructure for the Fort Peck tribes and reservation villages. A cooperative agreement will be made with the Fort Peck Tribal Executive Board for planning, designing, constructing, operating, and maintaining the Water System. The cooperative agreement outlines responsibilities for needs assessment, engineering, construction, water conservation, and contract administration. It also includes procedures for design and construction approval, as well as defining rights, responsibilities, and liabilities of each party. Optional provisions may relate to purchasing. The cooperative agreement may include provisions for purchasing, improving, and repairing water systems on the Fort Peck Indian Reservation. The Secretary can terminate the agreement if construction quality or system operation does not meet standards. Transfer of the agreement can occur upon execution. Transfer of funds to Fort Peck tribes for Water System under cooperative agreement. Service area limited to Fort Peck Indian Reservation. Construction to meet water supply needs. Title to Water System held accordingly. Title to the Water System will be held in trust by the United States for the Fort Peck tribes and cannot be transferred without Congressional authorization. Construction funds for the Water System cannot be used until environmental requirements are met, an engineering report is approved, and a water conservation plan is in place. The Secretary will provide technical assistance to the Fort Peck tribes for planning, constructing, operating, and maintaining the Water System. The system will be subject to the Indian Self-Determination Act. The Fort Peck tribes are required to develop a water conservation plan with specific goals and measures to conserve water effectively. The plan aims to ensure that water users utilize the best technology and techniques for water conservation. Additionally, the Reclamation Reform Act of 1982 applies to the Water System. The Water System will use power from Pick-Sloan for operation, with reserved power for future project use pumping. The rate for project use power will be the wholesale firm power rate for Pick-Sloan. Additional power needed can be purchased under appropriate terms by the Administrator of the Western Area Power Administration. The Administrator of the Western Area Power Administration can purchase additional power under appropriate terms for the Water System. Expenses for power purchases will be recovered through a separate power charge applied to the Water System. SEC. 7. WATER RIGHTS. This Act does not affect State water law, interstate compacts, water rights allocations, water quality laws, or the rights of the Fort Peck tribes based on treaties or compacts. It also does not grant non-Federal entities federal water rights. The Act does not impact State water law, interstate compacts, water rights allocations, or water quality laws. It also does not grant federal water rights to non-Federal entities or validate/ invalidate water rights held by the Fort Peck tribes or any other Indian Tribe under Federal or State law. SEC. 8. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. $114,734,300 authorized over 5 fiscal years for planning, design, and construction of Water System. Funds may be adjusted for development cost fluctuations. Additional appropriations authorized for operation and maintenance of the Water System.
